turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Any luck?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah. He finally agreed to let us have a room.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What about money?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Talked him out of it. He thinks we're going to stay a week. I'll have to think of something before morning.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: That's swell!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'm glad you think so. If you ask me, it's foolish. I told you there's no sense in our staying here tonight. We could make New York in less than three hours.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I couldn't arrive in New York at three in the morning. Everybody's in bed.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Okay.  Cottage Number Three.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes. You'll have a great story, won't you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah, swell.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Thank you.  Am I going to see you in New York?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Haven't you ever wanted to fall in love?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes. Haven't you thought about it at all? Seems to me you could make some girl wonderfully happy.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Maybe.  Suresure, I've thought about it. Who hasn't? If I ever met the right sort of a girl, I'd  Yeah, but where you going to find hersomebody that's realsomebody that's alive? They don't come that way any more.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Better go back to your bed.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I love you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You're forgetting you're married.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't care. I love you. Nothing else matters. We can run away. Everything'll take care of itself.  Please, Peter. You can't go out of my life now. I couldn't live without you.  Oh, Peter

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I hope you got your money.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You bet I did.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Congratulations.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Same to you.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why don't you stay and watch the fun? You'll enjoy it immensely.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I would. But I've got a weak stomach.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Compared to you, my friend, Shapeley's an amateur.  Whatever gave you an idea you can get away with this! You're positively the most conceited

turns.speaker: PETER'S VOICE
turns.text: Hey, wait a minute!  Let's get something straightened out right now. If you've any peculiar ideas that I'm interested in you, forget it. You're just a headline to me.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: A headline? You're not a newspaper man, are you?

turns.speaker: PETER'S VOICE
turns.text: I'll bet you're in an awful hurry to get back to New York, aren't you?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Goodnight, Mr. Warne.

turns.speaker: PETER'S VOICE
turns.text: ONETWOTHREEFOURFIVE

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why, you bully. I believe you would.

turns.speaker: PETER'S VOICE
turns.text: sixseveneightnine

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm out! I'm out!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Maybe I could jump out of the window.  Do you think they'd see me?

turns.speaker: PETER'S VOICE
turns.text: Come here, you little fool!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: There's a man here to see you, Sweetheart.

turns.speaker: PETER'S VOICE
turns.text: Whome?  Want to see me?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No, it isn't. I'm hungry andand scared.

turns.speaker: PETER'S VOICE
turns.text: You can't be hungry and scared at the same time.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Well, I am.

turns.speaker: PETER'S VOICE
turns.text: Comical part of it is, it isn't what you want at all. In a couple of weeks you'll be looking for the nearest exit . . .  People like you spend all your life on a merry-go-round. I guess that's what makes you so dizzy.  You're always chasing after something. At least you think you are. Truth is, you're just running away.  From yourself, mostly. 'Cause you're miserable. You hate yourself. The world's full of people like you. Don't know what they want.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Do you know?

turns.speaker: PETER'S VOICE
turns.text: I just want to be let alone, that's all. Life's swell if you don't try too hard. Most people want to get a strangle-hold on it. They're not living. They're just feverish.  If they didn't get themselves all balled up with a lot of manufactured values, they'd find what they want. Peace and calm. When you get right down to it, what's all the shootin' for, will you tell me? After all, you can only eat three meals a day, only sleep in one bed  Right now, that hay feels pretty good to you, doesn't it? Sure it does. 'Cause you were tiredand it's the only thing around.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You sound like a hobo.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Is that the Walls of Jericho going up?

turns.speaker: PETER'S VOICE
turns.text: Yep! The Walls of Jericho.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No harm in your coming to see us.

turns.speaker: PETER'S VOICE
turns.text: Not interested.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Won't I ever see you again?

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: How are you, Ellie?  Are you happy?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Happy? Why shouldn't I be happy? I'm getting the handsomest man in captivity.  Here you are, King. Let's drink.  Let's drink to us .  We finally made it, didn't we?

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: You bet we did.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's up to you now. I want our life to be full of excitement, King. We'll never let up, will we? Never a dull moment. We'll get on a merry-go-round and never get off. Promise you'll never let me get off? It's the only way to live, isn't it? No time to think. We don't want to stop to think, do we? Just want to keep going.

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: Whatever you say, darling.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I heard about your stunt. That's swell, King. Just think of itthe groom lands on the lawn with a plane. It's a perfect beginning for the life we're going to lead. It sets just the right tempo.  Come on, King. You're lagging.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Where's the bus to New York?

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Left twenty minutes ago.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why, that's ridiculous! I was on that busI told them to wait!

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Sorry, Miss. It's gone.  Ellie's face clouds. The crowds surge about her. She looks around thoughtfully. Suddenly her eyes open in surprise at something she sees, and the VIEW then moves over to Peter, who sits on his suitcase, looking toward Ellie.

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Eight o'clock tonight.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Eight o'clock! Why, that's twelve hours!

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Sorry, Miss.

turns.speaker: OLD LADY
turns.text: Here's your ticket, ma'am.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, thank you. Thank you very much.  Here.

turns.speaker: OLD LADY
turns.text: Oh, thank you. Thank you.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: When does the bus leave?

turns.speaker: OLD LADY
turns.text: In about fifteen minutes.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: What's the matter?  Where's your husband, young lady

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Husband?

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Yesif he is your husband.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Isn't he here?

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: No, he ain't! And the car's gone, too.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why, he'll be back.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Yeah? What makes you think so! He took his suitcase and everything.  Kinda surprised, huh? It's just like I told you, Zeke. They ain't married a'tall . . .

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why, you can't put me out in the middle of the

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Serves you right. Oughta be careful who you take up with on the road. You can't go plyin' your trade in my camp.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But can't you wait until morning

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Ain't gonna wait a minute.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Can I use your telephone? I want to talk to New York.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: You ain't gonna stick me for no phone calls. You can go down to the Sheriff's office.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: You made no mistake sitting next to me.  Just between us, the kinda muggs you meet on a hop like this ain't nothing to write home to the wife about. You gotta be awful careful who you hit up with, is what I always say, and you can't be too particular, neither. Once when I was comin' through North Carolina, I got to gabbin' with a good-lookin' mama. One of those young ones, you know, and plenty classy, too. Kinda struck my fancy. You know how it is. Well, sir, you could'a knocked me over with a Mack truck. I was just warming up when she's yanked offa the bus. Who do you think she was? Huh? Might as well give up. The girl bandit! The one the papers been writin' about.  Yessir, you coulda knocked me over with a Mack truck.  What's the matter, sister? You ain't sayin' much.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Seems to me you're doing excellently without any assistance.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: That's pretty good . . . Well, shut my big nasty mouth!

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: But I don't go in for that kinda stuffmuch. I like to pick my fillies. Take you, for instance. You're my type. No kiddin' sister. I could go for you in a big way. "Fun-on-the-side Shapeley" they call me, and the accent is on the fun, believe you me.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Believe you me, you bore me to distraction.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Hey, what's this? Wearing Papa's things? Now that's cute. That's what I call real lovey-dovey. Yessir.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: If you don't get out of here, I'll slap that fresh mouth of yours.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: SorryI didn't mean to

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Get out!

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Okay. I was just trying to make conversation.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Do you mind taking those things off the Walls of Jericho?  It's tough enough as it is.

turns.speaker: ELLIE'S VOICE
turns.text: Oh, excuse me.

turns.speaker: ELLIE'S VOICE
turns.text: Oh, by the waywhat's your name?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I've been thinking about you.

turns.speaker: ELLIE'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You've had a pretty tough break at that. Twice a Missus and still unkissed.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Heyyou not up yet? Come oncome on!

turns.speaker: ELLIE'S VOICE
turns.text: What time is it?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Eight o'clock.

turns.speaker: ELLIE'S VOICE
turns.text: I'm hungry.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Just your imagination.

turns.speaker: FIRST PILOT
turns.text: The old man's screwy!

turns.speaker: SECOND PILOT
turns.text: What's 'at?

turns.speaker: FIRST PILOT
turns.text: I said, the old man's screwy!

turns.speaker: SECOND PILOT
turns.text: Yeah!

turns.speaker: FIRST PILOT
turns.text: The dame's too smart for him.

turns.speaker: SECOND PILOT
turns.text: How'd you like to be married to a wild cat like that?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: FIRST POLICEMAN
turns.text: Bridge washed outaround Dawson.

turns.speaker: FIRST POLICEMAN
turns.text: Any of your passengers want a place to sleepthere's an auto camp up yonder a piece.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah? Where?

turns.speaker: FIRST POLICEMAN
turns.text: Up yonder. See the lights?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: FIRST POLICEMAN
turns.text: That's it. Dyke's Auto Camp.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Mr. Gordon

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Did you know he reversed the charges on that call?

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: What!  Say, listen you!  When you get back to New York, take my advice and stay f-a-r away from this officeunless you don't care what happens to that funny map of yours.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Here's another wire from Peter Warne.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Throw it in the basket.  What's it say?  "Have I got a story! It's getting hotter and hotter. Hope you're the same."

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Collect?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Don't accept any more.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Say, listen, you wouldn't know a story if it reached up and kicked you in the pants.  Yeah?  Sure, sure, I got your copy. Why didn't you tell me you were going to write it in Greek? I'd start a new department.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That was free verse, you gashouse palooka!

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Free verse, huh?  What the dickens was free about it? It cost this paper a gob of dough. Well, I'm here to tell you, it's not gonna cost us any more.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's okay by me! 'Cause as far as I'm concerned, I'm through with newspapers! See? I'm through with stupidity! I'll never write another newspaper story, for you or anybody else, if I have to starve.  Yeah? What about my novel! When I get through with that

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: When you get through with that, I'll have a beard down to my ankles.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Get out of here!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Wait a minute, GordonI

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Get out!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Joe, listen

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Don't "Joe" me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Okay, Joe. Listenyou know I've always liked you. Anytime I could do you a great turnanytime I ran into a story that looked goodI always came running to you, didn't I? Well, I got one now. Those wires I sent you were on the level. It's the biggest scoop of the year. I'm giving it to you, Joe.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: You mean about the Andrews' kid?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's it.  I got it all written up. Ready to go. All I want is a thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: A thousand dollars!  Get out of this office before I throw you out bodily.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Don't get sore, Joe. This is something you got to do for me. I need a thousand dollarsand I need it quick. I'm in a jam.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: What's the thousand bucks for?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: To tear down the Walls of Jericho.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: What!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Never mind . . . Listensuppose I should tell you that Ellen Andrews is going to have her marriage annulled.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That she's going to marry somebody else.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: You're drunk.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Would an exclusive story like that be worth a thousand bucks to you?

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: If it's on the level.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Well, I got it, Joe.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Who's she gonna marry?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's all right here. Give me the thousand and it's yours.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: I wouldn't trust you as far as I could throw that desk.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Wait a minute, Joe. Use your bean. I couldn't afford to hand you a phoney yarn, like that. I'd be crazy. There isn't a newspaper in the country'd give me a job after that! I could go to jail!

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: I'd put you there myself.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Sure. I wouldn't blame you, either.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Who's the guy she's gonna marry?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I am, Joe.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: You!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Now I know you're drunk.  I'm going home. Don't annoy me any more.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: For heaven's sake, Joestop being an editor for just a minute.  We've been friends for a long time, haven't we? You ought to know when I'm serious. This is on the level.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I met her on a bus coming from Miami. Been with her every minute.  I'm in love with her, Joe.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Well, I'll be

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Listen, Palyou've got to get this money for me. Now. Minutes count. She's waiting for me in an auto camp outside of Philadelphia. I've got to get right back. You see, she doesn't know I'm gone.  A guy can't propose to a girl without a cent in the world, can he?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thanks, Pal. You saved my life.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Okay, pete.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: 'Bye, Agnes. You're beautiful. All women are beautiful!  Gordon is immediately electrified into action.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Oh, boy! What a yarn! What a yarn!  Get me Hank on the phone. Gotta hold up the morning edition.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Hello, Joe. Sorry. Just a little gag of mine. Thought I'd have some fun with you.

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Yeah. Sure. Had me going for a while.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Wouldn't have made a bad story, would it?

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: Great!  But that's the way things go. You think you got a swell yarnthen something comes alongmesses up the finishand there you are.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah, where am I?

turns.speaker: GORDON
turns.text: When you sober upcome in and see me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thanks, Joe.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: All I'm asking is enough gas to get me to New York. The bag's worth twenty-five dollars.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Yeah, but I got a bag. My wife gave me one for Christmas.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Listen, manI'll tell you what I'll do. When I come back in the morning, I'll buy it back from you and give you ten dollars profit? What do you say?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: ain't got a hat

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: I ain't got a hat.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Well, you got one now. Come on, fill 'er up.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Funny couple, ain't they?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: If you ask me, I don't believe they're married.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: They're married all right. I just seen the license.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: They made me get 'em a rope and a blanket, on a night like this.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: What do you reckon that's for?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Blamed if I know. I just brung 'em a trumpet.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: A trumpet?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Yeah. You know, one of those toy things. They sent me to the store to get it.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: But what in the world do they want a trumpet for?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: I dunno.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You send telegrams here?

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: I'm just fine thanks, and how are you?  To "Joe Gordon, care of New York Mail, New York. Am I laughing. The biggest scoop of the year just dropped in my lap. I know where Ellen Andrews is"  No, do you really?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Go on. Go on send the telegram.

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: "How would you like to have the story, you big tub ofof"

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Mush. Mush.

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: "Tub of mush. Well try and get it. What I said about never writing another line for you still goes. Are you burning? Peter Warne." Well, that will be $2.60.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Send it collect.

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: Collect?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Collect.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: There you gotrustin' people again. How many times did I tell you

turns.speaker: OWNER
turns.text: He looked like an upright young feller to me, Ma.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Yeah. They're all upright till they walk out on you.

turns.speaker: OWNER
turns.text: Said he was gonna stay a week.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Mebbe.

turns.speaker: OWNER
turns.text: Worst comes to the worst, we got his car for security.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: I don't trust him.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: I told you! I told you, you couldn't trust him! He's gone!

turns.speaker: OWNER
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: That feller last night, that's who! He was gonna stay a week, huh? Well, he's skipped. Took the car with him, too. We wouldn't have known a thing about it until morning if I hadn't took that magnesia.  Come on, get up, don't lay there. Let's do something about it.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: See that. They're gone!

turns.speaker: OWNER
turns.text: Looks like it, don't it?  Here's the woman, ma.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Oh!!

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Thenyou'll have to git !

turns.speaker: OWNER
turns.text: Yeah, you'll have to git .

turns.speaker: OWNER
turns.text: Not a minute!

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Better start gettin' into your clothes.

turns.speaker: OWNER
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Zeke.  Git!

turns.speaker: OWNER
turns.text: Yes, Ma.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Well, you're two up on me now.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Hey, you!

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: There's a seat over there for you.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: What's the idea?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'd like to sit with myuhwifeif you don't mind.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Wife?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah. Come oncome on!

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Oh, excuse me.  I was just tryin'you knowto make things pleasant.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Looks like we're going to be stuck for a long time.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Say, Buddy

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Travelin' like this, you kinda lose track of what's goin' on in the world.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: If you wanna get anywhere nowadays, you gotta keep in touch with all the news, is what I always say.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Take that story there, for instance. Be kinda sweet if we could collect that ten thousand smackers.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeahwouldn't it?

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: It's a lotta dough. If I was to run across that dame, you know what I'd do?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: I'd go fifty-fifty with you .

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Cause I'm a guy that don't believe in hoggin' it, see?  A bird that figures that way winds up behind the eight ball,[10] is what I always say.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's on your mind?

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Five G'sor I crab the works.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You're a pretty shrewd baby.  We better get away from this gang. Talk this thing over privately.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Lucky thing, my running into you. Just the man I need.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: You're not making any mistake, believe you me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I can use a smart guy like you.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Say listen, when you're talkin' to old man Shapeley, you're talking to

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Do you pack a gat?[11] A CLOSE VIEW of the TWO shows the smile dying on Shapeley's face. He looks up quickly.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: A gat! A gat!  Got any fireworks on you?

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Whyno

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's all right. I got a couple of machine guns in my suitcase. I'll let you have one of them.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeahthe "big boy"the Boss of the outfit.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: You're not kidnapping her, are you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What else, stupid! You don't think we're after that penny-ante reward, do you?  Ten thousand bucks? Chicken feed! We're holding her for a million smackers.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Say, look! I didn't know it was anything like this, seeand

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's the matter with you! Gettin' yellow?

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: But I'm a married man. I got a couple of kids. I can't get mixed up with

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Sh-sh-sh! Soft pedal, you mug!before I What're you trying to do? Tell the whole world about it!  Now listen, you're in this thingand you're staying in! Get me? You know too much.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: I won't say anything. Honest, I won't.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah ?How do I know?  I gotta good mind to plug you.  I shouldn't take any chances on you.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: You can trust me, Mister. I'll keep my mouth shut.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Where do you live?

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Orange, New Jersey.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Got a couple of kids, huh?

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Yeah. Just babies.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You love them, don't you?

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Oh, gee, Misteryou wouldn'tyou ain't thinkin' about

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You'll keep your trap shut, all right.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: SuresureI'll keep my trap shut. you can depend on me, Mister.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If you don'tEver hear of Bugs Dooley?

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Nice guy. Just like you. But he made a big mistake, one day. Got kind of talkative. Know what happened? His kid was found in the bottom of the river. A rock tied around its neck. Poor Bugs! He couldn't take it. Blew his brains out.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Gee! That musta been terrible.  I guess he had it coming to him though. But don't you worry about me. I don't talk. I never talk. Take my word for it. Gee, I wouldn't want anything to happen to my kids.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Okay. Just remember that. Now beat it.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Oh, thanks, thanks, Mister. I always knew you guys were kind-hearted.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Come on, scram! And stay away from that bus.

turns.speaker: SHAPELEY
turns.text: Sure. Anything you say.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Boss, Oswald impersonators?  Sounds like James Bond now.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Al, you can't tell a mink from a coonskin unless you see the fur up close.  Goddamn, Sam!  If we don't start reading between the lines here! Y'all gotta start thinking on a different level - like the CIA does. We're through the looking glass. Here white is black and black is white.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: If this is Oswald, it must be our third Oswald.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: The interesting thing is the extent to which the Warren Commission went to make him a Communist.  They got almost 150 pages and 130 exhibits of the report on this Mexico trip and the picture doesn't even match.  I'm beginning to think the point of the Mexican episode was to lay the blame at Castro's door.  If Oswald, or someone purporting to be Oswald, had gotten into Cuba, come back, then killed the President, the American public once again would've screamed for a Cuban invasion...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Susie, watch the language, would you please.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: My instinct is that Ferrie is going to keep on deteriorating, and we'll end up getting more out of him when he finally cracks.  If we call him now, he might freeze up and we could lose the best shot we've ever had.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I don't care if he was doing it with giraffes in the zoo, Numa, it's none of our business.  Let's keep this side of it quiet, shall we?

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: When you're in a war, boss, you use every weapon you got.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Not one word.  That's an order.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: The U.S. Attorney in Washington "declines" to serve our subpoena on Allen Dulles, Charles Cabell, CIA Director Richard Helms, or any FBI agent we named.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, what do you expect from a pig but a grunt.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Without them, it's going to be near impossible, chief, to prove Shaw's connection to the CIA.  We got the same problem with the governors. All of them.  Reagan in California won't give us Brading, Ohio refuses Orville Townsend, Texas on Arcacha, and Nebraska on Sandra Moffet.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: William Walter, the night clerk on duty here in the FBI office, gave me a copy of this.  It went all over the country.  Nothing was done, and the motorcade went ahead on schedule - and this wasn't even mentioned in the Warren Report!  Read it, Al.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: "Threat to assassinate President Kennedy in Dallas, Texas, November 22-23.  Information received by the Bureau has determined that a militant revolutionary group may attempt to assassinate President Kennedy on his proposed trip to Dallas, Texas, etc, etc..."

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Gentlemen, I will not hear this.  I value Bill as much as anyone here.  We all need to make room for someone else's ideas, Lou, especially me. Maybe Oswald is what everyone says he is and I'm just plain dumb wrong.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: I've seen him copying files, leaving here late at night.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Why you keep dancing on my head for, my man?  We been thicker'n molasses pie since law school.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Because you keep conning me, Dean. I read your testimony to the Warren Commission and...

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: There you go.  Grain of salt.  Two sides to every coin.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You tell them the day after the assassination you were called on the phone by this "Clay Bertrand" and asked to fly to Dallas and be Lee Oswald's layer.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Now that's pretty important, Dean. You also told the FBI when you met him, he was six foot two.  Then you tell the Commission he was five foot eight.  How the hell did the man shrink like that, Dean?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: They put the heat on, my man, just like you're doing.  I gave'em anything that popped into my cabeza.  Truth is, I never met the dude.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yeah, she was pretty, all right, but not half as cute as you, Deano.  You shoulda tried a legitimate line of business.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: You can't ever say crime don't pay in Louisiana, Jim - only not as good as it used to.  Good chowder, ain't it?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: When did you first do business with this Bertrand?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Oh, I first heard these street cats jiving about him back in '56, '57 when I lived down in the Quarter.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Street cats?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Swishes.  They swish, y'know.  Young fags, you know.  They'd come into my bureau needing help, no bread, and I'd say, hey man, I ain't Rockefeller, who gonna back you up?  These cornmuffins go to the phone and dial...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What was his voice like?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: You knew you weren't talking to some low life fag, you know.  He had command of the king's English.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Did he pay?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Always - like tits on a pig.  I wish I had a million of those bimbettes.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: And Oswald?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Like I told to the Washington boys, Bertrand called that summer and asked me to help the kid upgrade his Marine discharge...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: So you saw Oswald how many times?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Three, four.  He came in with a few Cubano swishes one time I remember...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Recall any names?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Mario, Jose - they wear names like you and I wear clothes.  Today the name is Candy, tomorrow it's Butsie. I wish I could help you, Jim.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Did you speak to Oswald in Dallas?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Hell, no!  I told this Bertrand cat right off, this isn't my scene, man. I deal with muni court, I'm a hack in nigger town, that kid needs a hot dog.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Then how the hell did you get in the Warren Commission, Dean?  Except through the phone records in the Dallas jail?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: There were no phone records.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Of course there weren't. 'Cause they disappeared.  And yet the Commission found you, Dean.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I don't know how they got to me. Maybe cause I repped him here.  The Feebees run background checks.  On my mama's breasts, man, that's all I got.  There wasn't no conspiracy, Jim.  If there were, why the hell didn't Bobby Kennedy prosecute it as Attorney General, he was his brother for Chrissake.  How the fuck three people could keep a secret like that, I don't know.  It was Oswald.  He was a nut job.  Faggot, y'know, hated this country.

turns.speaker: BANISTER
turns.text: All this blubbering over that sonofabitch!  They're grieving like they knew the man.  It makes me want to puke.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: God's sake, chief.  The President was shot.

turns.speaker: BANISTER
turns.text: A bullshit President!  I don't see any weeping for all the thousands of Cubans that bastard condemned to death and torture at the Bay of Pigs. Where are all the tears for the Russians and Hungarians and Chinese living like slaves in prison camps run by Kennedy's communist buddies - All these damned peace treaties! I'm telling ya Jack, that's what happens when you let the niggers vote.  They get together with the Jews and the Catholics and elect an Irish bleeding heart.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Chief, maybe you had a little too much to drink.

turns.speaker: BANISTER
turns.text: Bullshit!  Bartender, another round...  Here's to the New Frontier.  Camelot in smithereens.  I'll drink to that.

turns.speaker: BANISTER
turns.text: Well, the kid musta gone nuts, right?  I said Oswald must've flipped.  Just did this crazy thing before anyone could stop him, right?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I think I'll cut out here, chief.  I gotta get home.

turns.speaker: BANISTER
turns.text: Get home my ass.  We're going to the office, have another drink.  I want some company tonight.

turns.speaker: BANISTER
turns.text: Who'd ever thought that goofy Oswald kid would pull off a stunt like an assassination?  Just goes to show, you can never know about some people.  Am I right, Jack?  Well, bless my soul.  Your eyes are as red as two cherries, Jack.  Don't tell me we have another bleeding heart here.  Hell, all these years I thought you were on my side.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Chief, sometimes I don't know whether you're kidding or not.

turns.speaker: BANISTER
turns.text: I couldn't be more serious, Jack. Those big red eyes have me wondering about your loyalty.

turns.speaker: BANISTER
turns.text: Who the hell opened my files!  You've been looking through my private files, haven't you, you weasel?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You may not like this, chief, but you're beginning to act paranoid.  I mean, you really are.

turns.speaker: BANISTER
turns.text: You found out about Dave Ferrie going to Texas today and you went through all my files to see what was going on.  You're a goddamn spy.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Goddammit chief, why would I ever need to look in your files?  I saw enough here this summer to write a book.

turns.speaker: BANISTER
turns.text: I always lock my files.  And you were the only one here today...  What do you mean, you son of a bitch?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You know what I mean.  I saw a lot of strange things going on in this office this summer.  And a lotta strange people.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Maybe there's more to this, Susie. The CIA's keeping something from our enemies.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Yes, but we're talking about a dead warehouse employee of no political significance.  Three years later and he's still classified?  They gave us his grammar school records, a study of his pubic hairs... Put it in context, Bill, of what we know about Oswald.  Lonely kid, no father, unstable childhood, high school dropout - wants to grow up and be a spy, joins the Marines at 17.  He learns Russian, he acts overtly Marxist with two other marines, but he's stationed at a top secret base in Japan where U2 spy flights over Russia originate.  He's discharged from the Marines supposedly because his mother's sick.  He stays home 3 days, then with a $1500 ticket from a $203 bank account, he goes to Moscow...

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: I don't know if it's coincidence, but Oswald had a top security clearance and knew about the U2 program from his days at Atsugi Air Base in Japan.  Six months after he arrives in Russia, Francis Gary Powers' U2 spy flight goes down in Russia.  That plane was untouchable. Powers hinted that Oswald could've given the Russians enough data to hit it.  As a direct result, the peace summit between Khrushchev and Eisenhower failed.  I can't help thinking of that book Seven Days In May, maybe someone in our military didn't want the Peace Conference to happen, maybe Oswald was part of that.  It gets weirder.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Susie, you're an assistant D.A., remember.  Stick to what you can prove in court.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: You want facts, Bill?  Okay.  From 1945 to '59 only two U.S. soldiers defect to Russia.  From '59 to '60, seven defect, six return, one of them another Marine a month before Oswald.  All of them young men made to seem poor, disenchanted.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Grab your socks and pull... Clay Bertrand is Clay Shaw...

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: No!... Shaw!  Director of The Trade Mart?  This is incredible.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Or a cover up!  Jesus, Bill, don't you have enough proof of the FBI's complicity now?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Maybe I have a little more respect for this country's institutions than you do, Susie.  You tell me how the hell you can keep a conspiracy going between the Mob, the CIA, FBI, and Army Intelligence and who knows what else, when you know you can't even keep a secret in this room between 12 people!  We got leaks everywhere! We're going to trial here!  What the hell do we really got?  Oswald, Ruby, Banister, Ferrie are dead.  Shaw - maybe he's an agent, I don't know, but as a covert operator in my book he's wide open for blackmail 'cause of his homosexuality.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Bill.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Hey, where y'at, Frank?  You're wasting your time here.  Big Jim gave strict orders.  No FBI allowed.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's you I want to talk to, Bill.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Boss would fry me in hog fat if he knew...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Your boss got a serious problem, Bill.  Real serious.  We know what's been going on at your office

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Yeah, I guess you do.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You've got nothin', Bill.  I'm talking as a friend now.  You're riding on the Titanic.  Time to jump off before you get destroyed along with Garrison.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Frank, I don't want to hear it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Senator Long set your boss up, my friend.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Who do you think fed him that information?  Garrison's going down. We're talking your career here, Bill, your life.  You're a young guy... we know you're working that Castro thing.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: No, I'm not...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yes, you are.  Look we know Oswald didn't pull that trigger.  Castro did.  But if that comes out, there's gonna be a war, boy - millions of people are gonna die.  That's a hell of a lot more important than Jim Garrison.  Goddammit, look at me when I talk to you!  You're too goddamn self- opinionated, now shut up.  If you got a brain in that thick skull of yours, listen to me.  Listen real hard.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Correct me if I'm wrong.  I thought we were on the same side.  What the hell business is it of theirs to say that?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Pretty fast, wasn't it.  The way they let him go.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What do you think, Lou?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: I'm just an investigator, Bill.  I leave the theories to you lawyers.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You, Numa?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's addressed to no one and no signature.  "To leave this life is, for me, a sweet prospect.  I find nothing in it that is desirable and on the other hand, everything that is loathsome."

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Pretty flowery for Dave Ferrie.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: The fact is he's gone, chief, and so's our case.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Not unless we go for Shaw now.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: With whose testimony?  Willie O'Keefe? A male prostitute.  Jack Martini?  A drunk?  Vernon Bundy?  A dope fiend. Shaw's got respect, the newspaper editors, the American Bar Association - they're not...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Yeah.  They were seen together in Clinton in early September.  The Civil Rights Movement was running a voter registration drive.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: ...rumor is Shaw, a local boy, was working on some arms deal to discredit the civil rights movement.  No one really knows what they were doing there, but everyone sure saw 'em. They stood out like cottonballs.  I got whites and blacks saw 'em, but last time I checked there was nothing illegal with registering to vote. We still got the Negro junkie, Vernon Bundy, saw 'em talkin' at the seawall near Lake Pontchartrain.  But it's tough, boss - no one wants to talk about Shaw.  He's...

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: You know you keep saying that.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Keep saying what?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: You're not digging.

turns.speaker: MOBSTER
turns.text: Clay Bertrand?  Sure I know him.  He comes around the Quarter.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Who is he, Joe?  I've been to every bar, no one wants to talk.

turns.speaker: MOBSTER
turns.text: I told your uncle I never met a lawman who wasn't a punk.  You too, Bill, even if you're family.  He's a big shot businessman.  I seen him on the TV news a lot with all the other big shots.  A fag, you know.  Goes by another name down here.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What's the other name?

turns.speaker: MOBSTER
turns.text: Shaw.  Clay Shaw.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Clay Bertrand is Clay Shaw?  The guy who used to run the International Trade Mart?

turns.speaker: MOBSTER
turns.text: Yeah, what's the big mystery? Everybody down here knows the guy.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: So why does he call himself Bertrand?

turns.speaker: MOBSTER
turns.text: Who gives a shit what he calls himself?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Clay Bertrand, Willie?

turns.speaker: O'KEEFE
turns.text: Yeah.  Clay.  I met him sometime in June of '62 at the Masquerade Bar. Dave Ferrie took me there, for the express reason to meet him.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Did he pay you for this?

turns.speaker: O'KEEFE
turns.text: Twenty dollars each time.  Hell, it's no secret.  That's what I'm here for.

turns.speaker: O'KEEFE
turns.text: ...there were about nine or ten people, Cubans, friends of Dave doing some stuff in the bush with him. Place was a mess.  Dave's mind was a mess,  Y'know he had all those mice cages around cause he's working on this cure for cancer... Dave's smart - real smart - speaks five languages, knows philosophy, medicine, military history, politics.  He wanted to be a priest but they defrocked him 'cause he was queer...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: And that's where you met Oswald for the first time?

turns.speaker: O'KEEFE
turns.text: Yeah, strange guy.  Dave introduced him as...

turns.speaker: O'KEEFE
turns.text: Fuck, yes.  Hell, I'm already in jail.  I got no reason to lie to you.  I ain't no nigger.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Go on, Willie.

turns.speaker: O'KEEFE
turns.text: ...well the party got crazier and crazier, one of those, y'know "beatnik" type things.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Hold your horses.  What kinda source?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: The anonymous kind, Chief.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Morning, boys.  Ready for a walking tour?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: At 7:30 Sunday morning?  It's not exactly fresh blood we're sniffing here, boss.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Old stains, Bill, but just as telling.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What the hell's a Communist like Lee Oswald doing working out of Banister's?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Y'ever heard of a double agent, Bill? I'm beginning to doubt Oswald was ever a Communist... after the arrest, 544 Camp Street never appeared on the pamphlets again.  Now here's another one for you:  What would you say if I told you Lee Oswald had been trained in the Russian language when he was a Marine?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Lord, wake me, please.  I must be dreaming.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, you're awake, Bill, and I'm dead serious.  And we're going to start by tracking down your anonymous source from three years ago.  How did you find out Dave Ferrie drove to Texas that day?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, it's a terrific yard, Chief, but the man's an obvious alcoholic with a reputation lower than crocodile piss.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Does that bother you, Bill?  I always wondered in court why it is because a woman is a prostitute, she has to have bad eyesight.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: He'll never sign a statement, boss, let alone get on a witness stand.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: When something's rotten in the land, Bill, it generally isn't just one fish, we'll get corroboration... find this Clay Bertrand.  If I were a betting man, I'd give you 10 to 1 it's an alias.  Start checking around the Quarter.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: And the six of us, with almost no budget and in secret, are going to solve the case that the Warren Commission with dozens of support staff and millions of dollars couldn't solve.  We can't keep up with the crimes in the Parish as it is, Chief.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: The murder of a President, Bill, is a crime in Orleans Parish too.  I didn't pick you because of your legal skill, you know.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Gee, thanks boss.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I'm lost, boss.  What are we saying here?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: We're saying that when Oswald went to Russia, he was not a real defector, that he was an intelligence agent on some kind of mission for our government and he remained one till the day he died, that's what we're saying.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: And therefore because Oswald pulled the trigger, the intelligence community murdered their own commander in chief.  That's what you're saying!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I'll go you one better!  Maybe Oswald didn't even pull the trigger, Bill. The nitrate test indicates he didn't even fire a rifle on November 22nd. And on top of that, they didn't even bother to check if the rifle had been fired that day.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: He had his palm print on the weapon.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: It went to the goddamn FBI and they didn't find a goddamn thing.  It comes back a week later and one guy in the Dallas police department suddenly finds a palm print which for all I know he could've taken off Oswald at the morgue.  There's no chain of evidence, Bill.  And what about the tow guns actually seen in the Depository?  One an Enfield photographed by a newsman and the other a Mauser, described by Deputy Weitzman... Maybe, just maybe, Lee Oswald was exactly what he said he was Bill - "a patsy".  Take it at face value.  Lou, Susie, I'm going with my gut here.  He's got an alias of Hidell to buy the rifle, "O.H. Lee" to rent the room, right?  What's in a name, right?  In intelligence, they're assumed to be fake.  A name is sort of like a postbox number, a code - several different people can use the same name, right?  Then why can't somebody be using Oswald's name?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: But why?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: To frame him, obviously.  You got to get in your minds how the hell spooks think, Bill!  They're not ordinary crooks.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I still have to question what the legal basis is that supports this, boss.  Susie's stuff is colorful, but...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Let's start making some assumptions about the man.  Why would he leave a path as big as Lee Harvey Oswald's? This is not a thin trail, gentlemen, it is a very wide one.  Who found the evidence?  Who set him up?  Lou, Bill, Susie, I want you to go back and check all the sightings of Oswald in Dallas, New Orleans and Mexico in the summer and fall of '63 - see if it's the same guy.
